abstract.p: Traditional methods for item selection in computerized adaptive testing only focus on item information without taking into consideration the time required to answer an item. As a result, some examinees may receive a set of items that take a very long time to finish, and information is not accrued as efficiently as possible. The authors propose two item-selection criteria that utilize information from a lognormal model for response times. The first modifies the maximum information criterion to maximize information per time unit. The second is an inverse time-weighted version of a-stratification that takes advantage of the response time model, but achieves more balanced item exposure than the information-based techniques. Simulations are conducted to compare these procedures against their counterparts that ignore response times, and efficiency of estimation, time-required, and item exposure rates are assessed.

sec.title: 1. Introduction

disp-quote.p: Computerized adaptive testing (CAT) is a method of administering a test that adapts to the examinee’s ability level to select an appropriate and informative item tailored to the examinee. CAT differs from the paper–pencil test format in that in CAT, examinees with different ability levels are tested with different sets of items. In a paper–pencil test, all examinees receive the same set of items. The purpose of CAT is to estimate each examinee’s latent ability trait θ precisely, and to select test items sequentially from an item pool based on the current performance of a test taker. The major advantage of CAT is that it provides more precise θ estimates with relatively fewer items than would be required in conventional tests. Examples of large-scale CATs include the Graduate Management Admission Test (GMAT), the National Council of State Boards Nursing (NCLEX), the Armed Services Vocational Aptitude Battery (ASVAB), just to name a few.

sec.p: Heuristically, when the test taker answers an item correctly, the next item selected should be more difficult. If the answer is incorrect, the next item should be easier. To implement this adaptive idea in a formal item selection procedure, an item response model that represents the person–item interaction should be defined. Item response theory (IRT) models are widely used to estimate both the characteristics of the test items and the ability levels of the examinees.

When a test is administered by a computerized test, the capability of recording the amount of time a test taker has spent on each item provides us with additional information about the test-taking behavior of individuals (such as whether the examinees cheat or not) as well as the characteristics of items. Recently, there has been considerable development on how to utilize response times on test items as an additional source of information in estimating the abilities of the examinees. Scheiblechner (1979) considered an exponential distribution for response times, whereas Maris (1993) has studied the gamma distribution. The second approach focuses on separate analyses of response times and response accuracy. For instance, Gorin (2005) regressed logtransformed response times on decomposed item difficulty parameters. Similar ideas were raised by Embretson (1998) and Primi (2000). A final approach advocates a joint modeling of both response times and responses; see, for example, Thissen (1983), van der Linden (1999a, 1999b), Roskam (1997), and Wang and Hanson (2005). Recently, van der Linden (2007) proposed a hierarchical framework in which response times and responses were modeled separately at the measurement model level, and response times were assumed to have a lognormal distribution. At a higher level, a population model for the person parameters (speed and ability) was constructed to account for the correlation between them. This model distinguished the speed–accuracy trade-off within a person from the speed–accuracy correlation in the population. Klein, Entink, van der Linden, and Fox (2009) further considered a Box-Cox transformation of the responses to adapt to more versatile response times distributions.

We use the lognormal model in van der Linden (2007) for response times, though our methods could easily be adapted to other models, and propose algorithms for item selection that uses response time information. Such methods can assist in controlling the amount of time required for a CAT, and in the appropriate circumstances can also be used in estimation of ability. Furthermore, we discuss the issue of item exposure and how the response time information can be incorporated in methods that control the item exposure rate. Next, we briefly review some technical details of CAT.

sec.title: 1.2. a-Stratification
sec.p: In large-scale CAT, many issues should be considered beyond efficiency of estimation. Among these are reliability and test security. One of the most commonly recognized drawbacks of information-based item selection method is that, no matter how large the item pool size is, only a small fraction of the items tend to be used. This poses a serious security risk. In order to address the test security issue, a-stratified item selection method (AST) was proposed (Chang & Ying, 1999 and Hau & Chang, 2001). With proper stratification and blocking techniques, AST can help balance the item exposure distribution, and hence yields the better test security while maintaining acceptable estimation efficiency.

The notion behind AST is that high discrimination parameters (a-parameter) are more useful in later stages of an exam than in the early stages when there is considerable uncertainty about the ability parameter. The item bank is divided into several strata, usually three or more, while ensuring the distribution of difficulty parameters (b-parameter) in these strata remains roughly constant. This is accomplished by ordering the items by their b-parameters and taking adjacent groups of M (number of strata), separating them into M different bins according to the size of their corresponding a-parameters. This results in M strata that have nearly balanced difficulty parameters, and nearly ordered distributions of discrimination parameters. Item selection in AST involves ascending through these M strata, matching
θ ˆ
with a similar difficulty parameter within the current stratum. The details of AST with difficulty blocking, and how it can be modified to adjust for response times are given in the next section.

The response time model yields simple closed form solutions to the terms needed to implement the MICT. Using this criterion, items with high information will tend to be chosen, but are less likely to be chosen if they require a great amount of time. By continually updating the speed parameter and the ability parameter, items may be chosen for an examinee that can assist in quickly accruing information about the examinee’s ability. By doing so, an exam with a fixed amount of information required can be completed more quickly, possibly affording the chance to seek a higher level of information by adding more items. Also, an exam of fixed length can be completed more quickly. The MICT and the MIC share the property that they do not balance item exposure rates well, and in the next subsection we consider adjusting for time in a-stratification.

sec.title: 2.2. Time Weighted a-Stratification
sec.p: One of the drawbacks of information-based CAT is that only a small fraction of items that possess high item information are selected. So the MIC and MICT could lead to extremely skewed item exposure rates, that is, some items could be constantly selected whereas others may never be used. Having too few items being used is not cost-effective and can lead to serious test security problems when the relatively small set of items being used becomes revealed to the public. To remedy this, Chang, Qian, and Ying (2001) proposed the AST with b blocking method (ASB) for item selection in CAT. The ASB method can be described in the following steps:

list-item.p: Arrange the item bank according to b values, and then divide the item bank into M equal-length blocks. So the first block contains items with the smallest b values, and the Mth block with the highest b values.

Further partition each of the M blocks into K strata according to their a values. Thus, in the mth block, the first stratum contains items with the smallest a values, and the Kth stratum with the highest a values.

For

Divide the test into K stages.

sec.title: 3.3. Results
sec.p: Table 1 displays the results for MIC versus MICT with N = 1,000 and the length of the item bank J = 500. Several covariance structures for the person parameters θ and τ and the item parameters b and β were considered. Two CAT exam scenarios were simulated: fixed length test and variable length test. In variable length test, the fixed Fisher information stopping criterion is employed. MSE for θ and τ estimation as well as the average time to complete the test were recorded. Both MIC and MICT estimated θ and τ very well with small MSEs in both fixed length and viable length tests. As expected, MIC’s estimation is slightly better than MICT’s due to the nature of the maximization paradigm. However, despite the small loss in efficiency, MICT substantially reduced the average time examinees took to complete the test. It is very desirable because it shows that with the information of response times, we can better control the duration of the exams, while getting very similar accuracy. If a fixed time limit is given, MICT would be superior to MIC because more items would be administered.

For the exposure control study, Table 2 lists the MSE for θ and β, the average time to complete the test, and the χ2 statistic for exposure contol. With no adjustment for exposure control, both MIC and MICT yielded very skewed exposure rate distribution with very high χ2 values. When ASB was in place, the values for χ2 were reduced considerably for both DM and time weighted difficulty matching (TWDM) item selection procedures. ASB_DM can be viewed as the counterpart of MIC whereas ASB_TWDM can be viewed as the counterpart of MICT. Figure 1 shows that ASB_TWDM and ASB_DM have substantially more evenly distributed item exposure rates than those of MIC and MICT, and are similar to one another.

As expected, when response time information was taken into account, the average time for examinees to complete a test was reduced. This was observed for both ASB_TWDM compared with ASB_DM and MICT compared with MIC, though the difference is more dramatic when comparing MICT with MIC.

Note: We implemented a-stratification with b blocking (ASB) with difficulty matching (DM) and time weighted difficulty matching (TWDM). Simulation was based on a 500-item bank, 1,000 examinees.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: Response times can potentially provide a wealth of information when exams are administered by computer. In this research we have considered how response time models might be used to improve item selection strategies in CAT. Item banks calibrated with both IRT and response time parameters allow for assessing speed along with ability. This extra piece of information allows for adjustments to almost any item selection strategy, and we have focused on adjusting the MIC and ASB. Simulation results show that far less time is needed to achieve the same amount of test information. Though we have focused on MIC and ASB, very similar adjustments could be done with the GIC, or even Bayesian item selection procedures. The lognormal model that we have used allows for closed form estimates of the speed parameter and expected response times, and no numerical integration is required. However, if there is a need to utilize a different response time model, the same definitions of MICT and ASB_TWDM apply, but could require more difficult calculations, depending on the model.

This research focused on utilizing time to accrue information quickly, but did not directly use speed in the estimation of ability. That is another potentially fruitful direction, but must be approached with caution. In item selection, we only maximize information of θ, and as pointed out by one reviewer, a future direction would be developing an item selection algorithm that considers both θ and τ. One possible solution is to treat θ and τ as from a “multidimensional” item response model, such that the joint likelihood for responses and RTs for a single examinee i is expressed as

The item selection methods developed for the traditional response based multidimensional adaptive tests, such as D-optimality or A-optimality (Mulder & van der Linden, 2009; Segall, 1996, 2001; van der Linden, 1999a; Wang, Chang, & Boughton, 2011) can be applied analogously. In summary, the rich information in response times should give rise to many challenging research problems that could lead to practical advances. Our aim was to focus on item selection in CAT, and even this narrow area of response time applications has many new directions for research and exploration.

The new method can be directly applied to current large-scale CAT programs. Its practical value is that it can help accrue more information within the same fixed time slot and can help avoid selecting extremely time-consuming items. Given a fixed time slot, more items may be taken. In situations with a fixed time and a fixed test length, duration will be handled much better to avoid speededness effects. The standard MIC algorithm may choose the items that are informative but may be very time-consuming. This gives a misleading impression of how efficient the item is for accruing information. Another practical issue that arises in CAT concerns content constraints. This was not considered in the current research, but existing methods for balancing content constraints may be adapted to also utilize expected response times in a similar manner.
